pros: People are fantastic. This college has so much potential for impact, and staff are all united to reach that potential

pros:
-A good amount of support: Example assignments and tests that you can use and adapt and an experienced professor to contact with any questions
-Not too much pressure or micromanaging
-Most staff are pleasant and committed.
-Plenty of remote (online with Zoom meeting) courses, so you may not have to commute to campus
cons:
A movement toward competing with private for-profit colleges has us:
1. squeezing in 6 terms per year instead of the traditional 2 semesters (or 3 with summer). Breaks are getting shorter. 
2. Offering more online and remote (online with Zoom meeting) courses and fewer in-person courses, which lead to instructors spending more time in training courses and the frustrations of trying to provide tech support to students

job_title: Teacher´s Assistant in Upper Marlboro, MD
pros: Great co-workers Great environment Flexible hours You get to help people
cons: No cons whatsoever, my colleagues were respectful and compassionate

pros:
The new president is smart and strategic. 
Coworkers are friendly and close knit.
Employees can work from home 2 days per week or a 4 day compressed work week option is available.
Students are diverse and more mature than traditional college students right out of high school.
Facilities are new, modern and well designed.
Convenient location and parking is free and easy.
cons:
Opportunities for career advancement seem limited in some departments.
Salaries seem lower than other Maryland community colleges.
Some institutional processes are slow, time consuming, and seem outdated.

pros: The college is under renovations and buildings are being upgraded over time. There are several more to be upgraded already in the pipeline. Everyone who I have encountered in over 2 years of employment has been nice to work with. Friendly environment.
cons: Salaries are stagnant and not competitive with the market. Despite the existence of a performance review process, their seems to be no system in place for staff promotions.

pros: Flexible schedule. Supportive environment. Good colleagues.
cons: Classes can be cancelled for low enrollment.

pros: The students are amazing and really appreciate everything the staff does. Staff, Supervisor, Directors, and Deans are the problem
cons: The leadership at this institution is unbelievable. As we began to work remotely they believed that it be best for LAYOFF Office Associates and didn't see the need for Office Associates to work remotely like other positions. The Deans hire their friends as opposed to skilled professionals and new talent. Supervisors lie on talented employees to keep them at the college. The college needs to be restructured with new leadership. The pay for Office Associates is also not as good as others. It is nearly impossible to grow in a place that is petty and only wishes to hold you back.

pros: Provost has great ideas to better college.
cons: Salary is very low compared to other colleges around.

pros: A culture of caring for employee and student success

pros: The college is good with maintaining schedules of employees and paying for their tuition if they or someone they claim on taxes goes to school.
cons: Communication skills from the top down are shotty, and the work culture is cliquish. Prejudice is not a thing amongst employees and students, but there is a dynamic of socioeconomic prejudice amongst staff, admin, and faculty.

job_title: Coordinator of Default Management in Largo, MD
pros: Job security, valuable work for the community
cons: Not a lot of support

review_title: Rather good place to work, if teaching is your only concern.
pros:
- adjunct faculty are permitted to receive the college's discounts on software and equipment
- employee tuition remission
- improved professional-development programs
- infrastructure's slowly improving (as in facilities, security initiatives, etc.)
- student-centered education, which is reflected in the College's values and mission
- strong family-centered organization (as in past and current employees are a family)
- a wide array of public programs for students, which is commendable for a commuter college
cons:
- for adjuncts, no traditional benefits (other than the aforementioned) nor the offer to buy into the college's plans (e.g., health, 403[b], etc.)
- one of the lowest pay ranges in the region for adjuncts
- no stability from semester-to-semester with regard to faculty (both full- and adjunct teacher) contracts
- a 27 credit-hour limit on the number of courses both full-timers and adjuncts can teach
- administrative matters are often a bit disorganized and are announced on short notice
- students report lackadaisical staff in student services-related departments

pros:
This used to be a great place to work. The students have struggles, but most are committed to their learning through some very difficult circumstances. The administration, as of late, has virtually collapsed. The basics are not getting done (they just missed a pay period for the entire adjunct faculty - as in NO PAYCHECKS - and the response to this on the part of the administration has been caviler at best), and the rising CYA attitude on the part of the administration in general has changed the vibe of the place in a very deleterious way. I love the students, but I am really not sure it's worth it anymore. 

The adjunct faculty is pretty spectacular. I love my colleagues. They are completely committed to our students and very knowledgable in their respective fields.
cons: As an adjunct, there is no room for advancement. These are part time positions which makes them ineligible for medical benefits (even for self purchase into the college based plans.)

pros: I love the teaching environment.
cons: The lack of supervisory supports.

pros: Talented faculty & staff.  Lots of facility improvements underway.
cons:
Senior administrators, VP and Pres, are back stabbers and are ripping-off PGCC students and county tax payers by giving themselves huge buy-outs and retirement sweet heart deals then rehiring themselves on extension contracts.  They are double and triple dipping on the public dime.

State and County elected leaders need to send in the auditors to find out exactly how tax payer dollars are being  ripped-off.  Then put an end to it!

pros: PGCC is a vibrant workplace where there are several types of people and activities occurring each day. No matter what department, all the employees seem to care for their jobs and work diligently. The students are pretty respectful as well. I enjoyed sharing ideas with other instructors.
cons: There are a lot of classes available but not enough fulltime positions. Although adjunct pays a good hourly rate, it lacks in consistency. To become fulltime you almost have to be hired for that need from the beginning, It is rare a fulltime opening is available.
